column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/ominous-stat-tied-to-bucs-coordinator-change/|Ominous Stat Tied To Bucs’ Coordinator Change|So CBS HQ dropped an interesting nugget yesterday. The Bucs are the fourth team in the Super Bowl era of NFL history to lose an offensive coordinator to a head coaching job in consecutive seasons. The first was the 1990 Redskins. Hey
column2: Todd Bowles played for that team! But those Redskins don’t really count because head coach Joe Gibbs was the offensive playcaller and mastermind
column3: per Joe’s research. Next was the 2007 49ers. After the 2005 and 2006 seasons
column5: playcallers Mike McCarthy and Norv Turner left the building. In 2007
column6: the Niners ranked last in the NFL in offense with only five victories. The last time a franchise was left in this predicament was the 2015 Ravens. They collapsed. Jim Caldwell bolted for the Lions head coaching gig after the 2013 season and a year later Gary Kubiak ran to the Broncos. Baltimore finished 2015 season with a 5-11 record. It was the worst season of John Harbaugh’s iconic head coaching career — by a mile. And here come the Bucs. Rookie playcaller Josh Grizzard has taken over for Liam Coen. “El Serpiente” is now the Jaguars’ head coach and 2023 Bucs offensive coordinator Dave Canales enters his second season running the Panthers. Very small sample size
column7: but it seems losing quality coordinators back-to-back is a major challenge. Yes
column8: Joe knows all about continuity and the Bucs’ desire to achieve it by promoting Grizzard. Smart move
column9: but it’s also wise to understand the offense will change a lot more than Bucs fans might be considering.|2025-02-21 16:54:00|256|21|3|Bucs' Coordinator Change|Losing coordinators consecutively poses major challenge for teams.|5|Fans express mixed emotions regarding coaching changes|"{""commenter0"": {""username"": ""FilthyAnimal""

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/bucs-shuffle-linebackers-coaches/|Bucs Shuffle Linebackers Coaches|When the Bucs last had a powerful edge rush
column2: their outside linebackers coach was Larry Foote. He’s back in that role again. Foote arrived in Tampa with the Bruce Arians-Todd Bowles regime and was tasked with teaching a Jason Pierre-Paul to play in a 3-4 defense (the Giants had him in a 4-3) and even (gasp!) drop in coverage. Foote also was asked to bring along a young free agent edge rusher named Shaq Barrett. Yes
column3: Foote did an excellent job but then was moved to coach inside linebackers for the 2022 season. The Bucs made it official today that Foote will move back to coach the outside linebacker. Joe is feeling good vibes. At inside linebackers coach will be another familiar face
column4: Mike Caldwell. He was Jaguars defensive coordinator in 2022 and 2023

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/overtime-sucks/|“Overtime Sucks”|NFL teams love to point to their records in one-score games as a way of spinning a positive projection. It doesn’t matter whether they won few or lots of those games. Losing many one-score games means you’re “this close” to greatness. Winning lots of them shows you know how to win and are mentally tough. Which is accurate? Joe can’t answer that. It’s an ultimate spin job. Last season
column2: the Bucs had a 3-6 record in one-score games
column3: including the playoff loss and a 1-2 record in overtime. Still
column4: Tampa Bay won 10 games. That overall reality has given Bucs players an internal confidence
column5: a feeling of being within reach of greatness. Joe has a similar feeling and thinks the Bucs are an edge rusher
column6: a punter and better defensive depth from being special. In 2023
column7: Tampa Bay was 3-4 in one-score games after going 6-4 with Tom Brady in one-score affairs in 2022. (Remember
column8: the Bucs had a legit defense in 2022). One-score games always have been a fun side note in Bucs history. Former head coach Dirk Koetter used to focus on them. Oh
column10: Koetter said. Then Koetter’s 2018 season featured a 4-7 record in tight games
column11: and that paved the way for the Bucco Bruce Arians regime. Joe once heard a Bucs official have the audacity to reference being competitive while losing 9 of 10 one-score games during the 2-14 season of 2014. Sorry
column12: no team is competitive while it goes winless at home like those 2014 Bucs did. Tristan Wirfs was talking close games on Media Row at the Super Bowl this month and noted to SportsGrid how “overtime sucks.” Joe heard that and immediately remembered how Wirfs was injured in overtime of the Bucs’ mind-numbing loss to a bad Browns team in 2022. Todd Bowles actually played for overtime that rotten day in Cleveland
column13: citing a fear of a Tom Brady interception. Wirfs and Antoine Winfield were injured in the extra period. Close games have consequences. And Wirfs is right. Overtime sucks. It’s a breeding ground for injuries and does a great job draining your team for the next game.|2025-02-21 14:20:00|360|17|2|Overtime|Impact of close games and overtime on NFL teams.|2|Mixed sentiments with criticisms on coaching

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/sec-defenders-on-daniel-jeremiahs-radar-for-bucs-at-no-19/|SEC Defenders On Daniel Jeremiah’s Radar For Bucs At No. 19|OK
column2: you know we are approaching draft season if Daniel Jeremiah holds a press conference about draft prospects. With the combine next week in Indianapolis
column4: the popular NFL Network draft analyst and former NFL scout
column5: gave his annual pre-combine press conference. He will have another one when the combine wraps up a week from tomorrow. (Before you hit Joe with: “But Joe
column6: the combine is still going on after Saturday… ” There is a difference between the combine the media attends and cares about and the combine the TV show seen on NFL Network. The combine the media attends is all the frontroom and backroom dealings centered in downtown Indianapolis with the beehive being the Indiana Convention Center
column7: which used to be the Hoosier Dome. It is packed with (some) NFL owners
column10: most head coaches and their assistants
column11: plus heavy hitter agents including but not limited to Tom Condon
column12: oily Drew Rosenhaus and Bob LaMonte. Also
column13: NFL media of all sorts is there. And yes
column14: the players. It’s sort of like the NFL’s winter festival. The combine the TV show that fans see from home is the underwear Olympics at Lucas Oil Stadium. “This Joe” has been to the last
column16: dozen combines and he has still yet to witness one iota of the glorified indoor track practice at Lucas Oil.) Jeremiah yesterday was asked specifically about the Bucs possibly looking for defense at No. 19. Joe knows the last time the Bucs picked at No. 19 was two years ago and it sure looks like Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht found a good one in Calijah Kancey. Jeremiah seems to believe the Bucs are going defense in the first round (which directly mocks his very different Bucs pick in his latest mock draft). And he thinks the Bucs may just grab one of two SEC defenders. Jeremiah likes the Bucs selecting linebacker Jihaad Campbell of Alabama as a no-brainer pick for Todd Bowles. “Well
column17: aggressive guys that can blitz from anywhere
column18: ” is how Jeremiah described what Bowles and the Bucs may be looking for. Jihaad Campbell would be sure as heck fun to watch there just with all the different things he can do
column19: and fast and explosive and smart. “That’s a good combination for Coach Bowles to be able to play with there. That’s the first thing that jumped off the top of my head here when I’m thinking about those types of players.” But wait
column20: there’s more. If the Bucs decided to go after an edge rusher instead
column21: Mykel Williams from Georgia is a guy to watch Jeremiah believes. “You can do a lot of different things with him in terms of rushing him inside
column23: ” Jeremiah said. “He’s athletic enough if you want to drop him. He can do a lot of those things as well.” Jeremiah said Campbell and Williams are “dynamic.” Joe loved Campbell last season. Williams? Dude didn’t have any more sacks than Campbell
column24: a linebacker. Both had five. Nah man
column25: five sacks playing against children doesn’t impress Joe. If the Bucs want to go defensive end (Joe hopes not only because name the last rookie edge rusher this coaching staff has developed?)
column26: Joe would much rather see the Bucs get Marshall’s Mike Greene
column27: who absolutely dominated Senior Bowl practices. Greene last year had 17 sacks in 13 games in 2024 — 17! That
column29: is production! Joe would have to find out exactly why Williams only had five sacks in 12 games if he is supposed to be such an otherworldly edge rusher. As far as Campbell coming in
column30: Joe would fully embrace it.    |2025-02-21 10:30:00|615|31|6|SEC Defenders|Daniel Jeremiah predicts Bucs draft defensive players from SEC.|4|Mixed opinions on draft priorities

column286: though (no pun intended).\u201d That\u2019s a sentence. The word \u201cthough\u201d and the parenthetical phrase can be ignored. The apostrophe replaces the letter \u201ci\u201d in the word \u201cis.\u201d Thus
column287: the core is \u201cHere is the catch.\u201d Subject? Check (the catch)
column288: Verb? Check (is). Complete thought? Check (just say it out loud). I confess to personally using non-sentences for rhetorical effect
column289: a perfectly acceptable practice among adult writers. And before you attack
column290: \u201cto personally using\u201d is not splitting an infinitive.""
